Cost of living and annual raise are rolled together and at the mercy of the University President, never to be more than maybe 3%. With one year of inflation at over 7% alone, you will literally lose money, never get ahead, and never get a raise. Once you get into the upper management positions it's different—you get a bigger salary, more vacation, better everything, but the low positions ('civil service') are not worth it. I liked my position, I liked my work. But I work to support my life and make money, that's the whole point. If you're mission-driven, go work for the State of Minnesota. Better benefits, better pay (cost of living and raises are separate, and negotiated by the union). One year later I'm making over 10k more in a similar position at the state.

review_title: I love everything about my job except the pay
pros:
You will not find better benefits anywhere, great people, tons of perks, working on campus is awesome, great coworkers, management depends on where you're working but there's a lot of great people working at the U of MN.

I have job security you can't find in the private sector, I know the work I'm doing is important and isn't based on what is going to be profitable to some shareholders or greedy CEO, and I work in an amazing lab. I am technically hourly but I don't have to report my hours. The plus is I can generally go home as long as my work is done, but I also never get overtime pay. Schedule is flexible and environment is relaxed and stress free.
cons:
The great benefits mean low take-home pay. 

Medica gets approximately as much money from the U of MN to pay my health insurance premium as I do (net) as a result of me working full time. If you count other benefits + retirement, the U of MN sends majority of what it costs to employ me to other people/companies.  At least I don't get taxed on most of that, but you have to admit it is a bit ridiculous-and it is high time the U of MN negotiate for lower premiums with no cuts in coverage.

I spent years in college, and I made more working behind a desk at a hotel than I do working as an accomplished academic researcher.

review_title: Wonderful place to work and learn and grow but salary on the low side
pros: UMN is an amazing place to work with outstanding benefits and the academic freedom to pursue my dreams. I also felt like the departmental 7.12 statements laid out criteria for promotion very clearly, though I understand there is a wide variation across internal colleges and departments. My colleagues were supportive and wanted me to succeed. The undergraduate CSE students are excellent, and the honors students are on par with students I taught at Northwestern or Berkeley, but with a more down to earth vibe. They also offer equal and automatic parental leave to both parents, regardless of gender. I felt highly valued, supported, and stimulated. Also, cross-department collaboration and intradepartmental collaboration was easy, common and valued without having to build my own siloed empire.
cons:
Despite the high ranking of the University and particularly CSE, salaries were lower than other Midwestern land-grant universities and members of the Big10. Starting salaries (and subsequent ones) are higher at UIUC, Ohio State, UW Madison, and obviously the private schools like Northwestern and U Chicago. 
Promotion and pretenure job retention are still heavily dependent on raising external and federal research dollars. These expectation were clear and up front, and certainly they are not responsible for decades of reduced funding at federal agencies, but it made achieving success precarious and undermined some of the collegial atmosphere. Standard for the field, but a downside nonetheless. Finally, UMN suffers from national and international cultural stigma against flyover country, particularly the upper Midwest. It's just not seen as vibrant or exciting as Silicon Valley, New York, Boston, the Rockies or the Pacific Northwest, which adds a roadblock to attracting a subset of the most innovative grad students who can pick where they go.
Also, the University is public and a huge employer in the biggest city in the region. Mistakes, bad behavior, cultural missteps, and crimes at the giant institution all make the front page of the Star Tribune, which carries a heftier social penalty than I would have guessed.

There are lots of opportunities to take classes and free courses online so if you want to learn new things or take an advanced degree at a discounted price of 75% off, working at the U would be perfect for you. There are also very minimal competition, more supportive for an admin job so I like it.
cons: The work can be stressful at times and there are many people who have been working at the U or a long time so if you are younger and newer to the job, there could be tension due to the fact that these coworkers only want things their way and dismiss anything you say. The finance and HR people were a bit difficult to work with and usually have long turnaround time for questions - but could just be the busy workload and lack of staff. Unfortunately, there are not a lot of room for growth. Usually you will have to quit and apply to a different department or college for a good raise.

review_title: Do not work for the University of Minnesota

When I asked multiple people why, they said they weren't responsible to provide a reason. Lies. I have worked more jobs than any individual person I know (30+). There is always a reason. They promise benefits, & time off. DO NOT TRUST THEM. If it suits their interest, they will fire you to for no reason. I am now at risk of homelessness because I was not planning on being fired. The University is a cult with the interests of the Elite and ONLY the elite. Do not subject yourself to them. Do not support the University of Minnesota.

cons: DEI is for optics, you are literally a token who does most of the work while your white colleagues can take off anytime. Management is run by a group of incompetent friends who hire their friends so you see no innovation and actual leadership. Not a safe place for a person of color. They will keep telling you are awesome but provide no room for growth and professional development. The U is so big there is no accountability of what happens in the colleges and individual units. It's literally run like a kingdom where you see the king once in a while who has no clue of what's going strategically as a unit or what's going on with their employees. They seemingly are also in cahoots with HR so don't even bother filing any complaint as it gets minimized and the emotional and psychological burden is on you as a person of color. I've been in several big ten institutions in Red states and never encountered such a dysfunctional system as the U. I really got a sense of "Minnesota Nice" at this institution.

pros:
I've worked for a number of units within higher education, from the department level to the college level, in a number of different roles. One thing they all have in common has been a good perspective on work/life balance. Hours are typically standard business 8-5, with a range of flexibility therein depending on your leadership. This includes remote options, especially since COVID, flexible lunch, and depending on classification adjusting work hours to suit family or personal needs.

Benefits are also very good. Our family opts for U of M benefits, which comes with staff perks ... such as reduced rate at the Rec Center, reduced rate for bike commuting, and other incentives to stay active while working--again, a very good sense of work/life balance. There is no expectation to be "chained to the desk."

The other thing is it's just great working on a university campus as large and diverse as the University of Minnesota. It's like living/working within a small town in a lot of ways and all your townsfolk are the students, staff, and faculty who make the place run.
cons:
After over a decade in higher education, it is a place that one could go and find a fulfilling career. However, there are a few drawbacks.

The first is the pay. It's generally lower than equivalent positions in industry. However, higher education (and education across the board) is largely under-funded, so if competitive salary is your goal, higher ed may not be where you want to land.

Related, opportunities for advancement are few and far between. I've only seen promotions twice in my career. One of my colleagues essentially created their own management role out of necessity and successfully made a case to the department, college, and various levels of bureaucracy to get a pay/title bump. The other promotion was standard fill/replace a manager from qualified internal candidates. There really aren't promotions or pay increases based on merit. You can expect a 1-2% raise annually which doesn't keep up with inflation rates, but the tradeoff is a sustainable, relatively low pressure working environment (though it can be stressful in ways you wouldn't expect---stakes can be very high, for very low stakes activities/goals, and progress can be slow, cumbersome, and confusing)

Lastly, leadership is a mixed bag. I've had great managers and very bad managers at all levels. This may be similar to any other industry, but, still, regardless, a con across the board. A bad manager can make a good job terrible. A good manager can make a bad job great. The axiom holds true in higher ed.

pros: Generally good work-life balance, friendly co-workers
cons: Let's start by saying the CIO doesn't share a formal strategy or business plan for the central IT organization. The CIO doesn't have control over IT teams outside of his own department. The senior directors in my structure rarely cared to provide all staff meeting updates (town halls). At non-management team levels, there is no talk about how well the broader institution is doing or how we are impacting the broader good. And if you are not in a job level equivalent to management level you are likely to not even hear about departmental and people changes unless it directly impacts you - and not rarely from the hallway. Project Management as a full rigor discipline is highly avoided, and often impossible as rarely individuals are dedicated to any one project. PMO was extinguished several years ago, and operations support personnel (including management) is unable to define the boundaries of operations vs projects. No meaningful metrics, lengthy documentation requests for approval, historical knowledge and little to no feedback or leveraging of them at all. By the way, procurement process (including RFP) is not considered part of the largest "projects". Management pretend to be open and supportive to ideas, but do not recognize their own mistakes and find ways to leave aside those who provide candid and constructive feedback against the status quo. Action plans for opportunity areas identified in engagement surveys are rarely put together, and I haven't heard or seen any testimony of any example of one carried out to the end.

review_title: All the incompetence in the Twin cities under one roof
pros:
- Good library - Walter Library is awesome!

- Part-time PhDs from the same university are recruited as full-time faculty or even professors in the same university. They hardly know anything. Some research professors even admit having never been inclined to read scientific literature. My advisor's PhD thesis committee member (another senior professor) informed me that my advisor as a grad student never read literature and was easy to pick on. 
- The most insecure group of faculty I have ever seen.
- Anti-male bias among the white women faculty. 
- Systematic breeding of incompetence where PhDs are awarded to imbeciles or for being imbecile. 
- Faculty tenure talks sound really cheap wherein white women speak about their domestic life or cry about how difficult it is to do science with kids instead of discussing the "Science" they've conducted. 
- Utter wastage of research money. You would rather invest that money to fix the lives of the homeless in the city. 
- PhD programs are some kind of women empowerment/ minority appeasement programs where faculty specifically select and train students who claim to be LGBTQ/single moms/divorcees/immigrants etc. just to make them look like they're resilient and intellectual. 
- Faculty are afraid of anyone real. They immediately gang up against them. 
- Should be ranked 1st from the bottom for research in biological sciences.

review_title: The Politics and Entitlement Burnt Me Out
pros: The Benefit Offerings were generous
cons:
Highly underhanded political environment with the key goal of getting away with anything and everything (all levels within the department) and not getting caught. Remember... "don't put it in writing"
Highly entitled multi-generational faculty and administrators that do not take no for an answer. There is no toeing the line with questionable behavior, just rubber stamp and again.. just don't put it in writing. This is why the University finds itself in the newspapers for a big blow up every year... they do what they want, when they want to. It's NOT the president, or any of her well intentioned initiatives.. she is an amazing asset to the university. Nor is it the Executives, or Deans for the most part either... these are forward thinking, innovative individuals who are focused on the University's mission.. it's a sneaky cluster of administrative bureaucracy within the units... provosts middle level administrators, and some very entitled faculty that make trouble. Lower level doer's (entry and mid level operations staff) who are for the most part, powerless, end up having to take the fall for this misdoings, whether it be being pulled into grievances, getting terminated for work ordered from their bully pulpit, or pulled through the ringer anywhere in between. I've witnessed this time and time again in my nearly 10 years of employment. I finally left the University and moved to the private sector after COVID added new struggles to an overall messy situation.

review_title: Totally depends on department you are in
pros: Good benefits (though they get a little less-good each year).  My department supports flexible work arrangements, but some don't.  Lots of vacation, especially if you've worked here a long time.
cons:
Pay is rock bottom compared to private sector.  Raises don't even keep up with cost of living.  If you start here early in your career, you're locked into super low pay forever. The only way to get somewhat better pay is to leave and come back.  

Most of the pros and cons depend on the department.  Some have good management, good processes, are forward thinking, know what their goals are.  A LOT of units have horrible management, lack of clear goals (or any goals at all), lots of cronyism.  

There's absolutely nothing that can be done if your department has bad management.  The dean or VP above your unit probably has NO idea what's going on, and doesn't want to.  There are no review processes for giving feedback on management to anyone.  

The U does an "engagement survey" annually (now every other year), and even if that uncovers serious issues in your department, no one steps in to correct them.  

If you get hired in a dysfunctional unit (more likely than not), change isn't going to happen.  Your only recourse is to find another job.

review_title: Same issues as for-profit workplaces, but more relaxed and better benefits.
pros: Work-life balance is excellent for non-faculty jobs. Work atmosphere is almost always casual to very casual. Benefits remain excellent even after recent cuts. Low level admin jobs can be nice if one works with many faculty, as they tend to be very appreciative--but there's always one!  Interactions with students are often very enjoyable. Mid-level and high-level mgmt jobs are becoming more specialized, and require Masters or higher degrees more often. That makes it feel like the U is becoming more professional in general, which is a good thing.
cons: Structured rather like a hospital: students=patients, staff=staff, professors=doctors. If you're staff, there are only limited ways to increase salary or responsibility. Advanced degrees required for some admin jobs masquerading as jobs close to content (public health, public affairs, etc.) so be careful. Faculty managers and directors have little to no experience or interest in management and operations best practices. Positions in operations like accounting are usually much less fun as there are many old, old timers in low level mgmt positions who still think it is 1964. Very bad in some places.Expensive to park/commute to (like downtown) and subject to many traffic delays in area. As a middle manager, I have shared sad war stories with friends in for-profit situations, and found the details not much different.

review_title: Supportive environment, but hard to attract good trainees
pros: The University has a good benefits package.  My department has excellent leadership.  The head is very communicative and "a straight shooter."  He is never misleading and tells you exactly where you stand.  The department has yearly reviews of junior faculty to assist in your self-evaluation.  There is also a formal mentorship program in which junior and senior faculty are paired for teaching and research.  Teaching requirements are minimal.  Overall, it's a very supportive environment.
cons: The quality of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows that you can attract is fairly low.  The highest quality lab members tend to be undergraduates and short-term technicians who are preparing for graduate school.  This leads to a huge and constant investment in terms of training new people. The climate can also be devastating in the winter if you're not from a similar climate.

pros: The people who do the day-to-day work are excellent colleagues. The benefits, although decreasing in recent years, are still some of the best available. A shift in view on how work is accomplished has led to flexible work agreements for many positions and work from home is now an option for those of us who don't have daily interactions with students or faculty.
cons: There remains a lack of transparency in some areas when it comes to budgeting and decision making. It sometimes feels like administration don't trust the people on the ground to do their jobs or make decisions that are in the best interest of a unit, college, or the university as a whole. Higher ed is still very much a hierarchical structure with faculty nested comfortably at the top and the contributions of staff are often undervalued and overlooked by central administration, however, department leadership is very supportive of staff and demonstrates appreciation despite push back from more senior leadership.

review_title: Progressive, relaxed atmosphere with good people, but lags in adopting modern standards and best practices
pros: Working at the U is very different than the corporate world. There is no expectation that I work over 40 hours/week, deadlines and due dates are hit-or-miss, expectations are minimal so it is easy to become a leader in the software development community on campus. People at the U generally share a progressive, liberal mindset, they are friendly and helpful, but don't expect them to be pushing the boundaries of the industry or modern technology, acting as early adopters, or working to become leaders in the industry.
cons: If you want to progress in your career or learn new frameworks or technologies you will need to press yourself, as your coworkers will likely be happy using the same stack they've been using for the past decade. It can be difficult to get a raise, usually the only way this happens is by interviewing in other University departments and forcing your current department to either bump you up or lose you. There is definitely a "slow lane" that you can get into where you aren't learning anything new and aren't actively working on challenges that make you a better developer.

review_title: Not for everyone - especially young professionals looking to advance
pros:
-  Great benefits - especially the Regents Scholarship.  Anyone interested in obtaining their 1st bachelor's degree (tuition 100% covered) or a masters degree (75% tuition coverage) it makes a HUGE difference!

-  The U of M seems to be a great place to retire or a place for those who find themselves in a director level position, have no desire to advance futher, and enjoy a relaxed schedule

-  You get to do great work by working for an organization that develops college students and prepares them for their next step in life.

-  Work/Life balance in my department is really great.  (I don't know that this is the case in every department.)
cons:
-  There is no such thing as a career track at the UofM.  There are no promotions.  If you are interested in moving up, you must apply to the job along with internal and external candidates with no guarantees.  Also, departments are often very small and very few individuals leave director-level positions resulting in minimal opportunities for advancement.

-  Pay is significantly lower than in a corporate setting.  There are no bonuses and raises are minimal

-  Job classifications can be limiting.  Employees at the U of M (in office settings) are put into 3 classifications: Bargaining Unit (union), Civil Service, and P&A.  Even though all three classifications will work together on a team, benefits (including vacation/sick leave and maternity leave) are not equal.  Also, bargaining unit employees are restricted from participating in certain opportunities outside their job description.

All of these have a detrimental affect on motivation and employee engagement.

review_title: Good benefits, good colleagues, very large (for better and worse)
pros: Like with other higher education settings, the biggest draw to me is the opportunity to work with like-minded colleagues and engaging students. People here are intelligent, generally liberal, and in most cases - not completely money-driven (if that is your style). The regents scholarship for reduced tuition for graduate degrees is a nice perk. The twin cities is a nice urban setting for a flagship state institution - most are in smaller college towns.
cons: The politics are a bit more frustrating than at smaller institutions where I've worked. There is more pressure to yield to administrators and faculty based on title and "importance," which can be frustrating. The size of the school can be good or bad. Employment in smaller colleges or sub-units can be rewarding. Offices or departments that serve the entire institution can be a lot of work and not a lot of repeated interactions and relationship-building given the enormous student population. Pay is not competitive with corporate or business positions requiring similar education/skills, but that should not be a surprise and higher education is not the place for you if salary is the top/primary factor in your career.

review_title: Inequities are written into contracts, unfair treatment of faculty.
pros:
Exploration of one's field is possible and encouraged when it serves the university monetarily.

Employees have a good health benefit and retirement package.

Access to explore new areas within your field is available if you work hard.
cons:
Adjunct contracts are written to allow the university to dismiss a professor without cause, without attention to seniority, as a way to make effective cuts to balance their budget.  

Harassment claims are dealt with in a way that the person claiming harassment is blamed for the harassment they experience.  This goes against their contract policy, but it is done.

It is mandatory for adjunct faculty to pay union dues without fair and equitable practices being accessible to them.  Their salaries are not created based on their experience or education or degrees, their salaries are lower that the US average for their degree and experience.

The university bestows higher salaries based on nepotism and reverse racism.  Adjuncts are used and discarded after decades of hard work given of their lives.

review_title: You get out what you put in as a TA
pros: As a Teaching Assistant at the University of Minnesota, the position is what you make of it. You will have access to amazing resources both in the form of physicals tools and brilliant people. You can just grade papers, proctor exams, and spend the rest of your time on studying or socializing. However, if you put in a little effort you can build a dialogue with people who will expose you to life-changing opportunities and ideas. Thanks to relationships I built with faculty, I was able to experiment in a cutting edge robotics lab, meet prestige guest lecturers, study abroad in a highly exclusive program, attend highly exclusive lectures, and learn some of the inside baseball of up and coming technologies and industries.
cons: Though the wage beats most service jobs, you usually don't have many hours. And the hours you do get are just enough that most other jobs won't on your remaining availability. So, if your main concern is money, this job isn't going to put a big dent in your tuition.

job_title: Extension Educator in Saint Paul, MN
pros: High level of appreciation for staff development and engagement in the organizations' development.  You really are on the cutting edge of research, education and what's the next "new" thing.  You certainly stay in the loop and it is greatly encouraged to stay up-to-date.  Great level of empowerment and buy-in for the mission from all levels of staff.  Very respectful and for the most part, very positive place to work.  The employee recognition programs, award programs and publicity around career successes are very strong and much appreciated.  Seem to communicate the organizations direction well to staff for the most part. Overall felt very positive about the organization.
cons: Work lots of hours in some positions; If you are in the field, tend to work alot of evenings and week-ends.  The benefits were quite good but the compensation felt really low compared to the amount of responsibility put on your plate and for the number of hours worked.  I think the number of hours worked each week has been addressed a little over the past year.  It is hard to have a fulfilling family life and do this job well unless your family is actually involved in the programs as participants that you are directing.    Feels like there is endless work to accomplish.

review_title: Keep a chair warm for 30 years
job_title: Information Technology Professional in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great benefits, low stress, stability. If you are looking for a place to plant your ass while waiting for retirement, this is it.
cons:
Promotions and raises are given for longevity, not merit, so the best employees tend to drop out of the bottom while the dead weight rises. Extremely conservative organizational culture; does not handle change well. Wasteful, outdated business practices. No accountability for mistakes, failures, or cost or schedule overruns.

If you are new to the company, it can be difficult to break in to the culture. People and processes have been in place for decades. Organizational momentum makes changing course nearly impossible. People tend to stay with the company for life. For these reasons, career growth opportunities are limited. Advancement opportunities within the company are limited. There is no reason to stay at this company unless your only criteria are low stress, stability, and good benefits.

review_title: Good place for postdocs, but don't get caught up in the system to try and secure a job here.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Excellent facilities, opportunities to collaborate in many different fields, opportunities for internal fellowship support, many aggressive and highly published groups to get involved with.
cons: Professors and staff try to entice people with temporary staff positions.  These positions have low wages (relative to other places like industry) and no/little benefits.  After three years of postdoc, if you haven't found a job (possible depending on the economic situation) you are transitioned automatically as a research assistant professor.  This position does come with benefits, but very low salary.  Those who have highly prestigious publications and have shown a high level of accomplishment are not treated any differently, although many professors will try to make them think something different will happen.

review_title: A very good place to work and learn!
pros: The University has a good benefits package, although I'm only a part time employee and thus do not qualify for the benefits. The job security at the U of M is good, as it is at most universities. At the University, there is room for advancement, which comes along with more advanced education. It is a good place to start out no matter where you want to go in your career as it opens many doors to many different areas. I don't plan to work at the University much longer, but I am glad that I have chosen to work at the University, even if for a short time.
cons: The university is so large that it is hard to see your impact. For example, the research I am doing affects the group I am working with greatly, but it is nearly impossible to see the effects to the University as a whole. There are probably better places to be employed if you like to see your impact, or maybe it just comes with working at higher postitions. Overall, the downsides are much smaller than the positives. I would recommend working at the University of Minnesota! Look into it yourself to get a better picture, but these are my feelings.
